Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Investigation of Discontinuous Galerkin Least-Squares Finite Element Methods for Singularly Perturbed Problems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this project is to investigate discontinuousGalerkin least-squares finite element methods (DG-LS FEMs) for
reaction-diffusion problems with singular perturbations. The numerical approximation of singularly perturbed problems is a practically important but still difficult subject. The analytical solutions to such problems typically contain boundary or interior layers, which cause nonphysical excessive numerical oscillations in the vicinity of layers in the solutions by standard finite element method and finite difference method. Many stabilization techniques have been developed to improve numerical solutions. The drawback of these techniques is the presence of problem-dependent parameters that need to be properly tuned according to a priori knowledge of layers, which nonetheless is not achievable in most complex problems. The DG-LS FEM is robust and efficient, which does not involve such problem-dependent parameters. The proposed research will advance knowledge and understanding of the DG-LS FEM as well as singular perturbation problems, provide a theoretical framework for the analysis of DG-LS FEMs, and establish a working principle of efficient and high quality adaptive schemes.

Singularly perturbed problems have attracted a lot of attention from engineers, mathematicians and scientists because of a wide range of important applications such as fluid dynamics, electromagnetism, semiconductor research, chemotaxis, genetics, and computational biology. Numerical approximations are usually the only way for solving such problems. There is an urgent need for a problem-dependent-parameter-free numerical method for singularly perturbed problems. This project is to develop creative solutions to fulfill this need, which will lead to reliable and efficient numerical approaches for solving complex singularly perturbed reaction-diffusion problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In science and engineering studies, boundary/interior layers and/or rapid changes in certain quantities describe strong and important interactions within the process(es), which have been in the focus of both theoretical and experimental researchers. In the computational mathematics community, numerical simulation of the solution to a process with layer(s) is a classical but still challenging problem. Standard numerical methods will fail unless special treatment is applied, which, however, usually depends on a priori knowledge of the solution. This project developed and investigated a new methodology for reaction-diffusion problems with layers in their solutions. This innovative method does not involve problem-dependent parameters and has a systematic framework, which allows it to be applied to a large variety of problems. Some challenging problems from biology, chemestry, and fluid dynamics have been studied to show the efficiency of the method. Research findings have been and will be disseminated in peer reviewed academic journals and professional conferences.

This project has trained three graduated students in numerical mathematics. In December 2015, G. Garcia (male, Hispanic) graduated from the MS in Mathematics program at Texas A&M International University (TAMIU) with a thesis entitled "Numerical Simulation of the Nagumo Equation by Finite Difference Method". In May 2016, H. Feng  (male, Asian) and J. Villarreal (male, Hispanic) graduated from the same program with theses entitled "Numerical Simulation to the Fitzhugh-Nagumo Model With Strong Reaction" and "Approximate Solutions to the Allen-Cahn Equation Using the Finite Difference Method", respectively. These students have reported their research findings in regional conferences and University conferences for students, and have won several prizes. In particular, H. Feng delivered a poster presentation in the 12th Annual TAMUS PATHWAYS Student Research Symposium at Texas A&M University at Corpus Christi, TX on October 22-23, 2015 and won the 1st Place in Master’s Level - Mathematics group (http://pathways.tamucc.edu/winners_masters.html). H. Feng has also co-authored two articles with the PI, both of which have been published in peer reviewed journals. On the other hand, this project has prompted undergraduate research in numerical mathematics at TAMIU. The students involved are mainly Hispanic due to the demography or structure of the student population (TAMIU has 92% Hispanic students). In particular, three students (2 female and 1 male, all Hispanic) have been actively engaged in the research activities of the project. They have also reported their research findings in University conferences for students.

Research findings from this project have been included in the PI's undergraduate and graduate courses, which enriched the course materials. This project allows the PI to invite a couple of numerical mathematicians to present their research findings to students at TAMIU, which due to limited resources is not a regular practice of the institution. Cooperation between the PI and national/international colleagues were also supported by this project.
